Half of the Yellow Sun¬†is set in 1970s Nigeria, balancing truth and fiction. Writer beautifully wrapped  a story of love, loyalty, betrayal, resilience and hope, in between the war. Through Adichie‚Äôs prose, we are offered a glimpse into the lives of several very different and multifaceted characters who are all determined to survive in the Free State of Biafra.¬†This book gives voice to the survivors and causalities of the war.¬†Half of a Yellow Sun¬†provides the reader with an experience that humbles, informs, and ensures that such stories are not lost in history. It is a tale that eloquently demonstrates what it means to be human, to confront your own mortality, to fight for a cause, to be vulnerable, and to be at war with oneself in the midst of political turmoil.

//Half of a yellow sun by Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie

Starvation was a Nigerian weapon of war. Starvation broke Biafra and bought Biafra fame and made Biafra last long as it did. Starvation made the people of the world take notice and sparked protests. Starvation made Zambia and Tanzania and Ivory Coast recognize Biafra. Starvation made parents all over the world tell their children to eat up. Starvation made the International Red Cross call Biafra its gravest emergency since the WW2.

Before getting into this book, I was oblivion to how the Nigerian civil war was fought, who Gowon and Ojukwu were, what Biafra was, and who Igbo, Yoruba, and Hausa tribe were. Upon entering into the well-crafted world of Adichie, I began to absorb like a sponge, too much at a time and giving little away. In the mornings, the sky was like a calm sea, by the evening, planes started flying low and fear spread throughout the body, red blood flowed across the streets, soldiers marched past and gently stroked the dead bodies to see if there was any life left. The half of a yellow sun glared from the torn sleeve of the soldier and later on the flag of Biafra. The only people left alive constantly muttered under their breath - "If the sun refuses to rise we will make it rise". Some knew they had to run before they're a dead piece. But, they couldn't muster the energy to move their scrawny hands and legs. They could only run and escape in their thoughts and pray to God to not be butchered in front of their family.

‚ÄúRed was the blood of the siblings massacred in the North, black was for mourning them, green was for the prosperity Biafra would have, and, finally, the half of a yellow sun stood for the glorious future.‚Äù

But war is not the only central theme here. With war, we have the story of a family, love, infidelity, friendship, and betrayal intersected in the lives of Ugwu, Olanna, and Richard.

Sita : Warrior of Mithila¬†is the second book of¬†Ramachandra series¬†authored by¬†Amish Tripathi. The book was preceded by¬†Scion of Ikshwaku¬†and will be succeeded by Raavan: Orphan of Aryavarta.

This book is a retelling of Ramayana and narrates the various stage of Sita‚Äôs life. Unlike the usual portrayal of Lady Sita as a demure princess and faithful wife shown in Ramayana, Amish‚Äôs Sita is a fierce warrior, an able administrator and a master strategist throughout the book. The character of Sita portrayed is so inspiring. Sita, also known as Bhoomi as she was found in a furrow, grows up as a doting daughter of the royal couple ‚Äì Queen Sunaina and King Janak.¬†
The fluidity in storytelling and the brilliance of visualization urges the readers to explore the multi-dimensional life of Lady Sita through various perspectives relevant even to this day.

We have seen Raavan as a unidimensional villain but here I love the Villain of all time ü§ó  The story Amish wrote is thought-provoking, particularly when it highlights problems such as the caste system, racism, patriarchal evils, poverty, addiction and child abuse.

Half Of A Yellow Sun/Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie 

A strring heartbreaking account of the Nigerian Civil War as seen through the eyes of three very different characters , Ugwu, Olanna and Richard. 

Ugwu, a thirteen-year-old houseboy who works for Odenigbo, a university professor full of revolutionary zeal. 

Olanna, the professor‚Äôs beautiful young mistress who has abandoned her life in Lagos for a dusty town and her lover‚Äôs charm .

 Richard, a shy young Englishman infatuated with Olanna‚Äôs willful twin sister Kainene.

I particuarly liked that the characters were great and their transformations seemed genuine, the book felt authentic and was evocative, the transition from normalcy to chaos was done perfectly. Reading about Olanna and Odenigbo's relationship felt real and the tribulations in their relationships were not overplayed. 

I came into this book not knowing much about the Biafran Conflict and came out feeling as if i'd lived through the experince, the brutaal honesty layered with tangible and relatable characters made the book more visceral and heartfelt especially the last few pages.

I'd absolutely reccommend this one.

üå∏Mental Health Talk 2

Half of a Yellow Sun portrays how people react to traumatizing experiences in their lives, including seclusion, alcoholism and having nightmares. One thing I appreciate about this book is the fact that it portrays an imperfect family surrounded by perfect love. 

The intense love between Olanna and Odenigbo helped them through the tough times. Even though they did not win the war, they were together through it all.  Love is the ultimate goal of life itself. To be born and share bonds of affection, to see our partners for who they are and choose to grow old with them, to see remorse and embrace them without a shadow of a doubt. Carrying each others burden with love so sincere. 

I have felt the butterflies in my tummy, giggled at his texts, lived for his calls and longed for his touch only to realize puppy love is for showbiz. It is not enough to love love but to live love. 

My take-home from this masterpiece is that we all struggle, maybe not at the same levels. We need love to go through it all. We need to normalize talking about mental health. Perhaps it‚Äôs time to rediscover yourself with love.

To kiss in the rain
To walk in the mud 
To hug under the sun
To cool under the moon
To love love 
To live love 

Till next time Catie and Winnieüå∏

üå∏ Mental Health Talk 1

I dare say in Africa, mental health is a synonym for ungratefulness. The African society has reduced mental health to mere excuses for not acting as expected of you. The community will remind you to be content, that unlike some, you are a complete biological being not missing a limb or toe; how lucky can one be? Definitely, jamming of the mind like everything else is solved by a pot of chicken or palm wine. 
As old and odd as that can be, I have no intention to awake our ancestors. They say, Let the bygones be bygones.

I worry about every little thing. I struggle with insomnia, conversations in my sleep which I don‚Äôt remember a word the following day, self pep talks and the ‚ÄòI should haves‚Äô. Nobody knows the dark side of our lives. It is lonely in there. I face my fears and struggle to be free daily. It may be anxiety or depression, or maybe it‚Äôs just part of the journey. It is very easy for society to condemn you as a social or a self-absorbed person. Your family and acquaintances may never understand because no one can ever relate to your mental struggles. 

One time I told my friend how I was struggling with anxiety and that I was praying for God‚Äôs grace. He quickly shunned me down and said that I couldn‚Äôt pray away what seemingly I had brought upon myself. So I shut my door, I pray a lot more for grace, and I promise you, it gets better every day. 

Mental health is considered a taboo in most African societies. We do not talk about it even in our families. Neither schools nor churches teach about mental health. Our brains are the most essential part of our body but even getting to that therapist office is damn expensive. Recently, I took a journey to rediscover myself through other people‚Äôs stories. In this journey, I met master Odenigbo struggling with alcoholism after the death of his mother in the Biafra war. Olanna was traumatized, having seen many dead bodies, including that of her uncle and aunt.

"The real tragedy of our postcolonial world is not that the majority of people had no say in whether or not they wanted this new world; rather, it is that the majority have not been given the tools to negotiate this new world." - Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie, Half of a Yellow Sun 

This historical fiction novel takes place prior and during the Nigerian Civil War (1967 -1970), also known as Nigerian-Biafran War or simply Biafran War. The ethnic, political and religious conflicts between the three dominant ethnic groups: Igbo, Yoruba and Hausa-Fulani fueled the war. It's a vividly haunting novel about postcolonialism, secession, morality, love, loyalty, betrayal, resilience and hope. 

This is definitely one of my favorite reads this year! I highly recommend this book for anyone who wants to read historical fiction that are not set during WWII.

Nigeria became independent from Great Britain in 1960. The¬†Nigerian-Biafran civil war¬†lasted from 1967-1970 and was marked by extreme starvation and ethnic violence. Ethnic tensions fostered by the British played a major role in the war. The majority of eastern Nigeria, was comprised of Igbo peoples, and this area seceded to create Biafra.

The 'half of a yellow sun' is the symbol of the Republic of Biafra, appearing on both its national flag and military uniforms. This novel follows the course of the Nigerian-Biafran civil war through the experiences of the ethnically Igbo characters, Olanna, Odenigbo, Kainene, and Ugwu.

Half of a Yellow Sun¬†is told in third person point of view in four parts. Each chapter marks a change in point of view, shifting between Ugwu, Olanna Ozobia, and Richard Churchill.
Twin sisters (Thandie Newton, Anika Noni Rose) from a wealthy Nigerian family take wildly different paths in life, but both become swept up in the struggle to establish Biafra as an independent republic.

Book of the Month: ‚ÄòHalf of a Yellow Sun‚Äô by Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie - A masterly, haunting new novel from a writer heralded by The Washington Post Book World as ‚Äúthe 21st-century daughter of Chinua Achebe,‚Äù Half of a Yellow Sun re-creates a seminal moment in modern African history: Biafra‚Äôs impassioned struggle to establish an independent republic in Nigeria in the 1960s, and the chilling violence that followed.

With astonishing empathy and the effortless grace of a natural storyteller, Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie weaves together the lives of three characters swept up in the turbulence of the decade. Thirteen-year-old Ugwu is employed as a houseboy for a university professor full of revolutionary zeal. Olanna is the professor‚Äôs beautiful mistress, who has abandoned her life of privilege in Lagos for a dusty university town and the charisma of her new lover. And Richard is a shy young Englishman in thrall to Olanna‚Äôs twin sister, an enigmatic figure who refuses to belong to anyone. As Nigerian troops advance and the three must run for their lives, their ideals are severely tested, as are their loyalties to one another.

Epic, ambitious, and triumphantly realized, Half of a Yellow Sun is a remarkable novel about moral responsibility, about the end of colonialism, about ethnic allegiances, about class and race‚Äîand the ways in which love can complicate them all.
